loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 34 years old and married with three children.  

She is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies.

Mary Ann has been farming rice for one year now, and has borrowed once in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, she would like to save enough to buy more farm lands.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
Rodrigo is a 53-year-old married man and father of two children from Leyte, Philippines. Rodrigo raises hogs and farms vegetables as his business. These are the sources of his income. 

Rodrigo wants to expand his farm but lacks the capital to do so. He is requesting a loan to buy feed for the pigs and fertilizer for the vegetable farm. Rodrigo will be able to grow healthy pigs and increase his vegetable harvest.  Rodrigo dreams of making his farming business successful.

loans.use: to buy feed for his pigs and fertilizer for his vegetable farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Oksana

texts.ru:
Оксана замужем. У нее есть один ребенок. Оксана имеет свой бизнес.

Оксана занимается продажей женской одежды на рынке на протяжении 24 лет. Она арендует торговое место. Оксана продает качественную и стильную одежду, которая пользуется спросом. Она трудолюбивый и открытый человек. Оксана хочет развивать бизнес и в будущем открыть вторую торговую точку.

Оксана просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 31 000 гривен на закупку женской одежды. Кредит поможет ей увеличить доход семьи.
texts.en:
Oksana is married and has one child. She has been running her own business selling women's clothing at the market for 24 years. She rents a retail stall and sells high-quality, stylish clothing that is in demand. She is a hardworking and open person and wants to develop her business and, in the future, open a second location.

Oksana is requesting a loan of 31,000 griven to purchase women's clothing. The loan will help her increase her family's income.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing for resale

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa is 37 years old and married with six children. With three children currently in school, Melisa works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a 30,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store.

Melisa has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as rice, detergent soap, coffee, sugar, soft drinks, noodles, and cereals. In the future, Melisa would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Norbelyn

texts.en:
Norbelyn is a 40-year-old married woman with five children. Four of her children are currently in school. She owns a fishing business in the Philippines and has requested a 8,000 PHP loan to purchase additional fishing gear. 

Norbelyn is a very hard-working entrepreneur and has been in this business for three years. In the future, Norbelyn would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing gear for her business.

loans.name: Bawi Lestari 1 Group

texts.en:
The Bawi Lestari 1 group paid all of the loan on time. With 7 members, they can keep their pigs well and they grow rapidly. The pigs stay disease free because they always give them vitamins and nutritious feed.

Ni Nengah, as the head of the group, succeeds in organizing the group and also selling her pigs. She earns 250,000 IDR per pig. She has 4 pigs. She’s really satisfied with the result. She says thank you to the lenders, Kiva and MUK for supporting her business. She keeps the profit to save for future needs.

The Bawi Lestari 1 group receives their fifth loan of the same loan amount and with the same members. The loan is used to purchase piglets, feed and to renovate the barn. The group still needs to borrow until they all have enough savings to use for capital.

With support from her husband, Ni Nengah continues with her loan and uses it to buy 2 piglets and also to support her husband's business as a salesman of wood for building materials. She wishes this time she will have more success and she can save more.

loans.use: to buy 2 piglets to raise and sell.

loans.name: Joventino

texts.en:
Joventino is a 60-year-old married man from Leyte, Philippines. He earns a living through his sari-sari or variety store business. He sells various goods and items to the people in his neighborhood.  Joventino has run this store for more than a year now. He  also raises pigs for additional income.

Joventino is asking for a loan to increase his inventory by purchasing items such as canned goods, noodles, soda, coffee, milk, sugar, salt, cooking oil, detergent and toiletries. This loan will be of great help because it will expand his store and generate more revenue.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell such as canned goods, noodles, soda, coffee, milk, sugar, salt, cooking oil, detergent and toiletries.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is 49 years old and married with four children. Prisca works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a 8,000 PHP loan to buy additional items like rice, canned goods, coffee, vinegar, juice, and noodles to sell.

Prisca has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items. In the future, Prisca would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items like rice, canned goods, coffee, vinegar, juice, and noodles to sell in her store.

loans.name: Andrea Marcela

texts.es:
Andrea tiene 20 años de edad, soltera  y está en el quinto año de la carrera de Administración de Empresas, estudio esta carrera porque le gustan las matemáticas y siempre pone en práctica lo aprendido.
En el trayecto de sus estudios la han apoyado su mama, sus tías y su abuela. Gracias a su esfuerzo obtuvo una beca en su universidad y para suplir sus gastos vende ropa variada. Andrea solicita el préstamo para comprar una computadora también así poder solventar los gastos de su graduación. El crédito le ayudara en gran manera ya que podrá manejar un nuevo equipo tecnológico así como tener mayores responsabilidades. 
Dentro de su plan futuro esta optar por un posgrado para luego encontrar un buen trabajo, su meta próxima es realizar su tesis y graduarse.
texts.en:
Andrea is 20 years old, single, and is in the fifth year of school for a career in Business Administration.  She studies in this field because she likes math and she always likes putting what she learns into practice. 

During the course of her studies she has always been supported by her mother, her aunts and her grandmother.  Thanks to her efforts she received a scholarship from her university, and to supplement her expenses she sells clothing.  Andrea is asking for a loan in order to buy a computer and also to pay for her graduation expenses.  The loan will help her tremendously since she will be able to work with new technology, and thus take on greater responsibilities.  As part of her future plans she would like to pursue post-graduate studies in order to find a good job.  Her current goal is to complete her thesis and to graduate.

loans.use: To purchase a computer and also to pay for graduation expenses.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma grows and harvests rice, work that she has done since she was married. She gets up early to go to the fields where she oversees her tenants as well as her crops. 

For many years in managing their farm, she has been able to improve it and has successfully repaid her previous loan used for fertilization costs. Her plan for the future is to have a comfortable home and to provide her children with a better education. 

She took a new loan recently from Gata Daku MPC to buy fertilizer and seedlings. 

In the future, Thelma wants to improve the general living situation of her entire family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn has faithfully repaid her previous business loan. She also has been operating her own house rental business for years and earns well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for their needs, especially for her children. The couple had to work hard, with the determination to have a better income. This would be used to provide their children with a better education, that they don't currently have.

To improve her profit, Evelyn would like to apply for a new loan for the maintenance of the boarding house. An amount of PHP 30,000 could already help her in the renovation and beautification of their place so that they could attract more boarders. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

Evelyn hopes to have more rooms that she could operate for business purposes. She also desires to become rich in the future. She meets up every week with her co-fellowship* members. Here, she shares stories of her work and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the repair and maintenance of her rental home.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 49 years old and married with four children. She is in the agricultural business, raising chickens in the Philippines. Rosita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her chickens.

Rosita has been raising chickens for four years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. Rosita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her chickens.

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en:
Rhodora is a 49-year-old married woman with five children, four of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Rhodora has a cultured seaweed business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials for her business, such as rope and containers. Rhodora has been in this business for one year. In the future, Rhodora would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy rope and containers.

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en:
Sherlita is a 39-year-old married woman with five children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Sherlita has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

Sherlita has been in this business for one year. In the future, Sherlita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Zecelyn

texts.en:
Zecelyn is a 42-year-old married woman with three children who attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Zecelyn has had a fishing business for 10 years and requests 5,000 PHP through NWTF to buy a fishing net and gasoline for her business.

 In the future, Zecelyn would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net and gasoline. for her business.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a furniture making business for 2 years.

Beatriz requests 12,000 PHP through NWTF to buy  wood, nails, and paint for her business.

In the future, Beatriz would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy wood, nails, and paintfor her business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a 38-year-old mother of two children. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. From the past many days his rickshaw is not working properly, so he is unable to generate any amount of income. He wants to repair it as soon as possible.

However, due to the lack of money, he finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairing his rickshaw. Therefore, Martha has requested a loan from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan, to help her husband to cover the cost of repair. This will help him to continue his business. Martha is so thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to cover the repair cost of her husband's rickshaw.

loans.name: Aneroselyn

texts.en:
Aneroselyn is a 24-year-old married woman with a 6 year old daughter.  She is from Concepcion, Iloilo. She and her husband have fished for 5 years.

Aneroselyn is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets and to pay for the repair of the fishing boat. This will enable her husband  to increase his catch  to sell in the market.

In the future, Aneroselyn hopes of making their business more profitable and sustainable. She also wants to save money to send her child to school.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and to pay for the repair of the fishing boat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To make improvements on his home in order to make it more comfortable for his child.

loans.name: Abida

texts.en:
Abida is a 25-year-old woman residing in Lahore, Pakistan. She maintains her house hold expenses  and has run a beauty salon for the last few years. She is good trained beautician. 

Due to her efficient and good work, her number of clients increases day by day. She needs additional items such as facial cream, combs,  chairs, and mirrors. 

Abida contacted Kiva's field partner BRAC Pakistan. BRAC staff visited her enterprise and issued a loan. She is very thankful to BRAC Pakistan and Kiva.

loans.use: to increase  her  beauty salon business.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is a 45-year-old married woman with four children, 2 attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Concepcion has had a vegetable vending business for 8 years and requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell to her customers.

In the future, Concepcion would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli is a married woman with seven children.  She is from Concepcion, Iloilo. Araceli and her husband have had a  fishing business for more than 25 years. This is their main source of income.

Arceli is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets to improve the catch and have more fish to sell in the market.

In the future, Araceli hopes to make their fishing business a success.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan is married with three children and lives in Mahayag Zamboanga del Sur with his family. He has been  operating a  repair shop  for many years and is  able to provide his family. 

The business is doing well and he needs new tools for his repair services. He will use the loan to buy an additional tool kit.

 In the future, he wishes to provide a better education for his children and  to have a better living for his family.

loans.use: to buy an additional tool kit.

loans.name: Eleuteria

texts.en:
Eleuteria works hard to support her family. Eleuteria is married and has had a native mat weaving business for 4 years.

Eleuteria requests 11,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more raw materials for her weaving business.

In the future, Eleuteria would like to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more raw materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Filma

texts.en:
Filma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has had a recyclable materials business for 8 years.  Filma earns additional income operating a general store.

She requests 20,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more recyclable materials to sell.

Filma has sustained her business through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure  her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase more recyclable materials to sell.

loans.name: Rizel

texts.en:
Rizel is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her as she was able to utilize the previous loan to pay for maintenance and  spare parts needed in her computer shop business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, house hold, and business expenditures.

Rizel now focuses on a new business venture, which is selling fruit. She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan  to purchase fruit needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to meet her daily needs and educational expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Rizel hopes for her business to become more established and will continue to help support with their everyday needs. She meets weekly with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work, and finds strength and inspiration from the word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase fruit and other products.

loans.name: Herbicilla

texts.en:
Herbicilla is married with  one  child and has helped her husband in their retail business for six years.  She was able to provide for the family and the  business is still doing well. 

Her husband had a vegetable garden and sold the produce in town while she runs a retail store in their village. She requests a new loan from Gata Daku MPC to purchase more grocery items to sell. She hopes to improve the living situation of her family in the near future..

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is a 32-year-old married woman with four children, all attend school. 

Rowena has raised pigs for 4 years  and has previously borrowed 2 times from NWTF to sustain the business. Rowena requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pig.

In the future, Rowena would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pig.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is 34 years old and married with one child who attends school, Marife works very hard to provide for them.

Marife has run a general store for 4 years and requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase canned goods, juice, seasonings, noodles, soft-drinks, milk, coffee, and detergent.

In the future, Marife would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase  canned goods, juice, seasonings, noodles, soft-drinks, milk, coffee, and detergent.

loans.name: Dan

texts.en:
Dan  comes from a middle class farming family. He is studying in the university and his  goal is obtain a position of leadership in his community and utilize his degree. 

Dan requests this loan so that he can pay his tuition fee for the first semester. This would allow him to continue his studies and have a better living in the future.

loans.use: to pay the school tuition fee for the first semester.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is 52 years old and married with four children. 

Pacita has raised pigs for 4 years and requests 17,000 PHP through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She has previously borrowed 5 times  from NWTF to sustain her business.

Pacita would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 36 years old and married with three children. Two children attend school and Mary Ann works very hard to provide for them.

Mary Ann has run a general store for 7 years and requests 19,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase canned goods, diapers, sanitary pads, shampoo, noodles, soft-drinks, and cereal to sell.

In the future, Mary Ann would like to save enough money  to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase  canned goods, diapers, sanitary pads, shampoo, noodles, soft-drinks, and cereal to sell.

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada is a 50-year-old married woman with five children. One child attends school.

Diosdada has raised pigs for 5 years and requests 16,000 PHP through NWTF to buy feed, vitamins and other supplies for her pigs.

She has previously borrowed 9 times from NWTF to sustain her business.

Diosdada would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and other supplies for her pigs.

loans.name: Yobana

texts.es:
La socia sigue dedicándose al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas, la socia continua vendiendo diferentes tipos de productos como arroz, azúcar entre otros, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de aceite, arroz entre otros.
texts.en:
The member is still running her grocery store. She feels grateful for the loan granted and she promises to make her loan payments. 

She continues selling different types of products like rice, sugar, and more, this being the way that she provides for her family. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of oil, rice, and more.

loans.use: to purchase oil, rice, and more

loans.name: Suratmi

texts.en:
Galang is the second of  five siblings. His older sibling just graduated from high school, but he is not at school and does not work. HIs mother's name is Suratmi.

His parents do not earn enough to pay for school and meet the daily living needs. He has graduated from junior high school and does not want to drop out of school as his brother did.  He wants  a better future. However, it is unlikely he can go to school with the family's economic situation and 3 younger sisters. 

He is interested in a vocational program in Yos Sudarso Majenang and the educational assistance program of  KIVA. He enrolled in vocational school Yos Sudarso Majenang in hopes of passing vocational school.  He walk  1 KM to school every day.  Suratmi asks for this loan for her son.

loans.use: to pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada works hard to support her family. Diosdada is married and has had a general store business for 6 years.

Diosdada requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more stock items to sell in her general store.

Diosdada would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Noelyn

texts.en:
Noelyn is a very hard-working woman who is striving to be able to become successful in the future. 

She is studying Human Resource Management  to have a better career and help her family.

She requests this loan to pay her tuition fees and cover her educational expenses. She is grateful for the opportunity that she is receiving fom Gata Daku MPC.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fees and cover the educational expenses.

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia is 59 years old and married with six children, 1 attends school.  Lucresia works very hard to provide for them.

Lucresia has run a general store for 6 years and requests 17,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

She sells a variety of items such as rice, eggs, bread, coffee, cooking oil, and vinegar. 

Lucresia would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie is a 44-year-old married woman with five children, 3 attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Marjorie has had  a  mat weaving business for 4 years and requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional raw materials for her business.

In the future, Marjorie would like to save enough money  to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional raw materials for her business.

loans.name: Zareena

texts.en:
Zareena is a 43-year-old married woman, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of six children.

 Her eldest son owns a small business to sell ready-made garments at a shop. He purchases clothes from the market at a low price and sells them for a profit. The towns people  like his garment collection. The demand for clothes has increased because the winter weather has started and people are demanding warm cloths. 

Her son meets all the expenses with his earnings and is able to save as well.  He wants to increase his current business but he does not have sufficient capital.  Therefore his mother, Zareena, requests a loan so that her son can buy a variety of garments to meet the demand. 

She is very thankful to Kiva and field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to enhance in her son's  garments business.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe DANAYA sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à OUAYERMA I un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur dix-huitième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro-finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame JAKILINE debout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes DANAYA, fait la vente des  condiments . 
 Elle compte acheter avec son prêt  des quantités importante de condiment d’où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses marchandises pour la revendre en détail au marché à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the group DANAYA are married women, who average 39 years of age and five children each, all living for the most part in traditional families in OUAYERMA I, a working-class district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  

The women are on their 18th solidarity loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers. 

Ms. JAKILINE, who is standing first from the left in the photo in this women’s group DANAYA, sells condiments. She intends to use her loan to purchase significant quantities of condiments for which she is much in demand by her customers for the quality of the merchandise. She then makes her sales at the retail level to men and women customers paying with cash or credit at the market. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used to pay back the loan with interest, and part goes toward savings.

loans.use: to purchase condiments

loans.name: Djantoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJANTOYERELA ont en moyenne 37ans, 3enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à YANGASSO/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales et des condiments.
Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJANTOYERELA sont à leur 6èmeprêt solidaire.AWANI, 2èmefemmedela droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter10Kgs de mil, 10Kgs de fonio, 15Kgs de farine de blé, 15Litres d’huile, 5Kgs de Sel, 2Kgs de piment et 1 demi paquet de Cube Maggi. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes.Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de16 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group DJANTOYERELA average 37 years of age and three children each, all living in traditional extended families in YANGASSO/SEGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship, and they have businesses buying and selling grains and condiments. 

After having correctly paid back their previous loans, the women of the group DJANTOYERELA are on their sixth solidarity loan. AWANI, the second woman from the right in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase: 10 kg of millet, 10 kg of fonio, 15 kg of wheat flour, 15 liters of oil, 5 kg of salt, 2 kg of chili peppers, and a half packet of Cube Maggi [bouillon]. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers. She makes her sales to men and women customers paying with cash or credit. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 16,000 francs CFA that will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food, clothing, and schooling. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase grains and condiments

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: Abla est revendeuse de boisson, des pagnes et d'autres produits dans sa boutique, depuis 2004, Abla pour renforcer son activité sollicite un premier crédit pour acheter des marchandises afin de répondre aux besoins des clients. Elle espère assurer l'épanouissement de la famille tout gardant pérenne son activité. Abla âgée de 41ans est mariée et mère de 02 enfants de 7 et 5ans scolarisés.
texts.en: Abla has been a vendor of beverages, ’pagnes’ (the colorful cloth of western Africa), and other products in her shop since 2004. To bolster her business, she is requesting an initial loan to purchase some merchandise to respond to customer needs. She hopes to ensure her family thrives while keeping her business sustainable. Abla is 41 years old and a married mother of two children, aged 7 and 5, both in school.

loans.use: to purchase beverages, ‘pagne’ cloth, and general merchandise

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJEKAFO ont en moyenne 30ans, 5enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à SANTORO II l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des habits, des fruits, du savon et des condiments.
Les femmes du groupe DJEKAFO sont à leur 1erprêt solidaire.ALICE, 1èrefemmedeboutde la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter7 cartons de savon. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes.Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group DJEKAFO average 30 years of age and five children each, all living in traditional extended families in SANTORO II, a district of SAN/SEGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship, and they have businesses buying and selling clothing, fruit, soap, and condiments. 

The women of the group DJEKAFO are on their first solidarity loan. ALICE, the woman standing first from the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase 7 boxes of soap. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers. She makes her sales to men and women customers paying with cash or credit. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food, clothing, and schooling. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase soap

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME ont en moyenne 45ans, 5enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à YANGASSO/SEGOU (laquatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des ustensiles, des volailles, des céréales et des condiments.
Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME sont à leur 15èmeprêt solidaire.SADIO, 2èmefemmede la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter10Kgs de mil, 10Kgs de pomme de terre, 15Kgs de maïs, 15Litres d’huile, 5Kgs de Sel, 2Kgs d’oignon et 1 paquet de Cube Maggi. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes.Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group DJIGUISSEME average 45 years of age and five children each, all living in traditional extended families in YANGASSO/SEGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship, and they have businesses buying and selling utensils, poultry, grains, and condiments. 

After having correctly paid back their previous loans, the women of the group DJIGUISSEME are now on their 15th solidarity loan. SADIO, the woman second from the right in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase 10 kg of millet, 10 kg of pototoes, 15 kg of corn, 15 liters of oil, 5 kg of salt, 2 kg of onions, and a packet of Cube Maggi [bouillon]. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers. She makes her sales to men and women customers paying with cash or credit. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food, clothing, and schooling. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase grains and condiments

loans.name: Mougnoussin Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe MOUGNOUSSIN ont en moyenne 48ans, 5enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à SANTORO II l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des habits, des fruits, du savon et des condiments.
Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe MOUGNOUSSIN sont à leur 2èmeprêt solidaire.ELISABETH, 1èrefemmeassisede la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 1 carton de savon, 1 carton d’eau de javel, 10Litres d’huile, 10Paquets de bonbon, 15Kgs de lait en poudre et 2 cartons de biscuit. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes.Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de16 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group MOUGNOUSSIN average 48 years of age and five children each, all living in traditional extended families in SANTORO  II, a district of SAN/SEGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship, and they have businesses buying and selling clothing, fruit, soap, and condiments. 

After having correctly paid back their previous loan, the women of the group MOUGNOUSSIN are now on their second solidarity loan. ELISABETH, the woman sitting first from the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase a box of bleach, 10 liters of oil, 10 packets of candies, 15 kg of powdered milk, and 2 boxes of cookies. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers. She makes her sales to men and women customers paying with cash or credit. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 16,000 francs CFA that will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food, clothing, and schooling. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of grocery items

loans.name: Teofista

texts.en:
Teofista works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Teofista requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

She has been in this business for 15 years now.

Teofista would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative in the year 2012 and she appreciates the programs, services and continuous education of the co-op. She is a member in good standing and very active in attending the various programs and services that the Cooperative offers. 

She is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000. This loan is intended to restock her food stall business.

Juanita dreams of nothing more than having a happy, healthy life and an adequate income out of her business.

loans.use: to restock her food stall business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel has high hopes of owning a house with enough savings from her retailing business. She wants to have comfortable living conditions. Her membership with PMPC has helped her with her financial needs. She was able to increase her inventories and is able to send her children to school. 

Now she availed a loan to buy housing materials to complete the construction of her home. In the future, she hopes to buy farmland to cultivate and be another source of income.

loans.use: to buy housing materials to complete the construction of her home.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes, 63 years old, lives in Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines. She was gifted with five children. Lourdes is the breadwinner of the family. She has experienced hardships, especially in raising her family. This industrious member finds herself plowing the rice field, planting vegetables and other varieties of agricultural commodities.

In need of additional working capital, Lourdes decided to join Paglaum Cooperative. She has received several loans already and recently requested PHP5,000 to buy farm and garden fertilizer and to pay for labor costs for cultivating their land.

Being a MIGS member (Member in Good Standing) of the cooperative, she has been able to manage her income. She is able to provide for the daily needs of her family. Lourdes is very thankful because if it were not for Paglaum, she might not have any savings or be guided properly in her finances.

loans.use: to purchase garden and farm fertilizer and pay labor costs for land cultivation.

loans.name: Dynna

texts.en: Dynna is engaged in a retailing business and supervising the completion of the construction of their home. Dynna hopes to live comfortably in a house with good roofing supported by her loan of PHP 45,000. She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing with a good repayment record.  Dynna has given a priority to her membership with PMPC and she wants to start a piggery to earn more income. This is what she is thankful for when all her financing needs for her retailing business and piggery were supported by PMPC.

loans.use: to complete the construction of her house and buy more pigs

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her as she was able to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another PHP20,000 loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Helen hopes for her business to continue to flourish, and she only wants a simple life for her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Duo Mujeres Alegres Group

texts.es:
DUO MUJERES ALEGRES ll
Este dúo está conformado por Maria Olga ella es originaria de Sumpango,es casada y madres de familia, el negocio que tiene es la agricultura y los tejidos se dedica a sembrar frijol, ejote, güicoy entre otras verduras, todos los día se levanta desde muy temprano para poder trasladarse en los terrenos en donde siembran las semillas, es el cuarto crédito que solicita con kiva ya que necesitan comprar abono para poder colocarlo en el terreno, ellas están muy agradecidas por la ayuda brindada de kiva ya que gracias a los créditos ha sacado adelante a sus hijos que tiene y que están estudiando.
texts.en:
The "Mujeres Alegres II" Duo

One member of this duo is María Olga who comes from Sumpango. She is married and a mother. She has a farming business and also knits. María grows beans, string beans, courgettes and other vegetables. María wakes up very early in order to arrive on the land where she plants her seeds. This is María's fourth loan from Kiva; she needs it in order to to buy manure for her land. 

Both members of this loan group are very grateful for the support provided by Kiva. Thanks to loans, they have been able to help their children who are in school.

loans.use: to buy manure for growing her vegetables.

loans.name: Paulina Doris

texts.es:
La socia Paulina sigue dedicándose al negocio de venta de leche, la socia lleva años dedicándose a este su negocio el cual le trae satisfacciones personales, la socia Paulina pertenece al banco comunal “San Bartolomé de Tambo Real” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma,
La socia solicito el crédito para la compra de leche.
texts.en:
Paulina continues to make a living with her business selling milk. She has been doing this work for years, and she finds it satisfying on a personal level. Paulina is a member of the "San Bartolomé de Tambo Real" of the "Asociación Arariwa" organisation. She is grateful for this loan opportunity and promises to make her repayments on time.

Paulina is applying for a loan in order to buy milk.

loans.use: to buy milk.

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Mr. Efren, 55 years old, is married and a resident of Olingan Dipolog City Zamboanga del Norte. He earns a living by raising ducks. He has been a member of PMPC for four years and enjoys the privileges of being a member of the Cooperative. Now, he is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase native chickens and ducklings to sell.

Efren deeply wishes to remain a member in good standing with PMPC.

loans.use: to purchase native chickens and ducklings to sell .

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en: Rhoda, 37, is married with three school-age children. Her major source of income is buying and selling assorted products like bags, cosmetics, sandals and even kitchenware. She has been in this business for nine years already. The business helped her meet her family's financial needs, especially the education of her children, until they graduated and got jobs. She is still continuing the business because it provides good income due to her loyal customers. Someday she will have a legacy to leave to her children. Her plan is to maintain her inventory so that her customers will be served well. She is still planning to expand her business for the good of her children and even her grandchildren. She received loans previously to purchase additional stocks, and now she is re-applying a loan for her buy-and-sell business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Luna

texts.en:
Luna is a microfinance member of PMPC. She is thankful to the cooperative for trusting her with her financial needs. She has purchased original pigs and started her backyard hog raising business. 

Recently, she obtained  a loan to purchase bags of feed and animal vitamins for her chosen business. Luna wishes to continuously manage her business more effectively with the support of her family.

loans.use: to purchase bags of feed and animal vitamins

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda busies herself doing her farming activities. She has a personal touch with her chosen business. She signed up for membership with PMPC and has maintained a good repayment record. Rosalinda didn't give up when she experienced odds in her business, especially when there was low production. To increase her inventory for the next cropping season, she applied for another loan to buy three bags of fertilizers. 

Rosalinda perseveres and always believes in reaching her goals to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy three bags of fertilizers

loans.name: Maria Arlene

texts.en: Maria Arlene, 49, is a widow who has two children. She resides in Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. She operates a videoke entertainment business and at the same time, a retail store to make a living. She is also vending fertilized duck eggs and is earning very well from this. She became a member of Gata Daku MPC and has borrowed a new loan to buy grocery goods, snacks and soft drinks for her video bar. She had to expand her business in order to gain more returns and be able to provide her children with a better living in the future.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods, snacks and soft drinks for her video bar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for more fruits needed in her business.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her as she was able to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children, in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 9,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Jennifer still desires to improve her service and should attract more customers. She dreams only of success through all her hard work. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fabric, cloth, thread, needles and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Carosel

texts.en: Carosel finds pleasure in farming. Not only does she count it as a hobby but she earns an income as well. At the age of 20 and a mother of one, she keeps herself busy to sufficiently provide for her child. She has a farm that her parents provided her to have a source of income and she started growing rice on it.  The GDMPC provided her capital to support her farming activities. Recently, she applied for a loan to purchase fertilizer and some portion will be use to buy additional grocery goods for her retail store. In the future, Carosel wants to settled with her own family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to buy additional grocery goods for her retail store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase many different kinds of  food materials to be able to meet all the demands of her customers.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is a married woman and a mother of two children from Leyte, Philippines. Maricel used to run a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and items to locals. But she was forced to stop after the super typhoon, Haiyan, ruined her store.
As of now, Maricel has just started to make repairs to her store. She is requesting a loan from CEVI to buy stock for her store like canned goods, noodles, soap and toiletries, soda and beverages and cooking ingredients. Maricel believes that through this loan, she will be able to sell goods to her neighboring customers. In the future, Maricel hopes of expanding her store so that it will generate more income.

loans.use: to buy stock for her store like canned goods, noodles, soap and toiletries, soda, beverages and cooking ingredients

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Before, Susan requested a loan to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from this business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Susan hopes for her business to continue growing and improving in terms of sales. She has always desired good health for her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of food materials, goods, and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia is in need of more capital to invest in her retail store to have more goods to offer and to renovate her store. This will allow her to increase her stock levels and have more revenue. She wishes to continue working and generating income to get ahead with her family. Her sales and profits have improved and her family lives a comfortable life.

Claudia decided to request a new loan because of the positive effects it generates. This loan will help her to purchase more variety of grocery goods to sell. She wants to offer more goods each time to her customers and to keep improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more variety of grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Om Kamal Group

texts.en:
This group is called Om Kamal. It consists of four women who are all hardworking. They live in Hodeidah City, Yemen. They have taken a loan of 70,000 YER. 

Aesha is 49 years old and married with four children. Her oldest child is 15 years old and the youngest one is 2 years old. She is living with her family in their own house. She is an uneducated woman, but she knows her advantage very well. She has a strong determination to improve the living standards of her family. Aesha has started her own business with a small amount of money that she saved herself. She invested that money in her own business. She started her business many years ago selling incense and perfumes in order to help her husband with the expenses of the family. She sees this business as a profitable one for her. For further expanding her business, Aesha requested a loan of 15,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase more  incense and perfumes to resell to women in her area.

Aesha expects a boost in her income and will enroll her children in a private school. She hopes to renovate her old house.

loans.use: to purchase more incense and perfumes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the university installment for this semester.

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.en: Dionisia is a 56-year-old married mother of three children from Leyte, Philippines. She is engaged in making hollow blocks. She has been in the business for more than 2 years now. This is the source of her income. Dionisia is asking for a loan to buy cement, sand and screens. With thi loans, she and her husband will be able to make more hollow blocks to sell, thus augmenting their sales and income.  Furthermore, Dionisia hopes to make their business a success.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and screens

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen, 36, is the mother of four children. She lives with her spouse and children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband is a greengrocer by profession, and he has been selling fresh fruits at a shop in a nearby town for many years. Her husband offers seasonal and fresh fruits to his customers. He has been feeding his family through the income generated from this fruit shop. 

Nowadays, the needs of his family have suddenly increased and he does not have other sources to cope with these needs. So he decided to expand his current business. He wants to increase his stock on a daily basis so that he can maximize sales of the fruits. Therefore his wife, Nasreen, requested a Kiva loan. 

She is thankful to Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase in her husband's fruit sale business

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve has been operating her upholstery business for four years, and she earns a good income. Having a large family requires more effort to provide for their needs, especially for her children. She and her husband work hard, with the determination of earning a better income, to provide their children with a better education.

In order to increase her services, Salve is requesting a new loan for PHP 30,000 to purchase additional raw materials. These include more quantities of foam, fabric, nails and other supplies needed in her business. She sincerely expresses her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.
In the future, Salve hopes to open outlets inside and outside her community so she could cater more customers. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week, where she finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for materials like fabric, nails, foam and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is 34 years old, married, and together with her spouse they have been blessed with two children. She has a quarrying business, and has been doing it for three years now. 

She will be using this loan to buy more quarrying tools such as mattock, hammers, and chisels. This will enable her to supply more building block and make more profits, which she will use to provide for the needs of her family.

This is her fifth loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and she has been paying her previous loans successfully. In future she hopes to grow her business and be successful.

loans.use: To buy more quarrying equipments.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Hello lenders. Meet Purity, a very industrious, honest and hardworking woman from the Chuka area of Kenya, near the famous Mount Kenya. Purity,43 , has been farming for the past 20 years. Through these years, she has gathered much experience and is considered among the best farmers in her village. She has been practicing mixed farming. Her primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, tea, crops and some small business ventures that help her make ends meet. 

Purity is very passionate about farming and loves cultivating her farm. That is why, every day, she wakes up very early to go to her farm to plow. Although she makes profits from farming, she is not comfortable and has always wanted to increase her income by selling cereals. That is why she is seeking this loan to buy cereals. Kenya's Chuka area, one of the county's populated regions, has a high demand for cereals. This means that Purity could increase her profits and satisfy the demand that is there. 

Accessing funds has been a challenge for Purity, but she now feels relieved because Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva lenders to help aspiring women farmers like her turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing. Purity believes that this loan will be of much help, and that she will be able to satisfy the demand for cereals. She also believes that the extra income she earns will enable a permanent change in her life and increase her business. Increased profits will allow Purity to repay this loan and secure the future of her school-going children.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 46 years old, married, and together with her spouse they have been blessed with four children. She has a retail shop and has been in this business for 20 years.

She will be using this loan to buy more stock of retail goods such as rice, flour, cooking fat, and salt. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children, and also repay the loan.

This is her second loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and she paid her previous loan successfully.  In future she hopes to grow her business, make more income, and live a better life together with her family.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Rosildis

texts.en:
Rosildis signed up for her membership with PMPC and obtained the needed capital to start up a sari-sari store business. She is thankful for the capital that was extended to a small-time borrower like her. Rosildis is able to turn the tide in her favor and is making good sales these days. She wants to take advantage of the good fortune. 

Recently, she took a loan to restock her store with basic commodities, like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce. 

In the future, she hopes to build a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to restock her store with items like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Shagufta

texts.en:
Shagufta is the age of 36; she is the mother of two children. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband owns a lPG gas sale shop in the town.  He has been running this business for many years. He buys LPG gas cylinders from the main market at a wholesale rate, and sells at a retail rate from his shop to earn profits. He manages his household necessities from his own shop as well. He speaks with an even tone, which is impressive and he easily wins the trust of others. Due to his behavior and tone, he has built up very good relations with his customers. His LPG gas sale shop is very famous in the town, and that is the reason his business is running well.  

He wants to increase his business. Therefore, Shagufta has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to increase his LPG gas sale business. Shagufta is so much thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase in her husband's LPG gas business

loans.name: Yecika

texts.es:
La socia Yecika se dedica al trabajo como obstetriz, ella trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene varios años en este trabajo, el sueño de la socia es tener una clínica de obtetricia.La socia solicita el crédito para comprar equipos para su consultorio.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Yecika, the borrower, works as a midwife. She works from 8:00AM until 6:00PM. 

She has been doing this work for some years. Her dream is to have an obstetrics clinic. She is asking for a loan to buy equipment for her practice.

She is happy for the loan and she agrees to making her loan payments.

loans.use: to buy equipment for her practice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy soups, basic grains, sweets, eggs, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
La socia Irene sigue dedicándose a la producción y venta de leche, la socia vende su mercadería a sus clientes que le solicitan, la socia está muy agradecida con KIVA por ayudarla a desarrollarse en su actividad y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas puntualmente, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de una vaca.
texts.en:
Irene continues dedicating herself to producing and selling milk. She sells her merchandise to customers who request it. 

She is very grateful to Kiva for helping her develop her activity and she promises to make her loan payments on time. This is the way she supports her family.

She is asking for a loan in order to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Rosa Stefany

texts.es:
Rosa es una joven emprendedora, con muchas ganas de salir adelante, trabaja en una Botica de su ciudad natal, Subjantalla. Ella es muy responsable, está sacrificándose por sus hermanos porque quiere que ellos tengan un mejor futuro y una educación de calidad. El motor de su vida es su familia, por eso no le importa sacrificar muchas cosas, solo porque quiere el máximo bienestar de su familia.
Rosa está agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado podrá comprar una ropero para sus hermanos, de esta manera podrán guardar su ropa y estará en mejores condiciones. Más adelante Rosa quiere empezar su propio negocio de farmacia porque ya adquirió muchos conocimientos en este rubro. ella seguirá esforzándose para sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en: Rosa is an enterprising young woman with many wishes to move ahead. She works in a pharmacy of her native city, Subjantalla. She is very responsible. She is working hard for her siblings because she wants them to have a better future and a quality education. The motor of her life is her family. For them she does not mind giving up things; she only wants their best. Rosa is grateful to the Kiva lenders because thanks to their support she will be able to buy a wardrobe for her siblings. This way they will be able to put their clothing away and keep it in better conditions. Later, Rosa wants to start her own pharmacy business because she already learned a lot in this area. She will keep on working hard to move her family ahead.

loans.use: To buy a wardrobe to furnish her house.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo is a 38-year-old fisherman from Dulag, Leyte. He is married with two children ages 2 and 12. To earn a living, he has worked as a fisherman for 12 years now. He usually earns 20,000 PHP per month. Reynaldo needs additional capital to make his business a success. He will use the loan to buy an engine, a fishing boat and fishing nets. 

Reynaldo works hard for his children and hopes that in the future he can expand his business and make it prosperous.

loans.use: to buy an engine, a fishing boat and fishing nets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to continue buying mobile phone recharge cards.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
This is Miriam. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise products needed in her direct selling business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures.
 
At present, she manages her own variety store and she earns well from this. She would like to apply for another loan and this time amounting to PHP 18,000. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Miriam dreams of expanding her variety store and she also hopes that her children will be able to complete their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week. This is also where she can draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Hina

texts.en:
Hina is a 29-year-old woman. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother of two children. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. He has been running an auto rickshaw for the last five years. From the past many days his rickshaw is not working properly because of which he is unable to generate any amount of income. He wants to repair it as soon as possible. However due to the lack of money, he finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. 

Therefore, Hina has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. This will help him to continue his business. Hina is so much thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to cover the repairing cost of her husband's rickshaw.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a 34-year-old married man and a father of two children. His oldest child is 13 years old and the youngest one is a 10-year-old. Khaled lives with his family in their own house in Haja, Yemen. He is an educated man. 

Many years ago, Khaled purchased a piece of land and built his own house on that land. That undertaking cost him a lot of money. Now, Khaled and his family are experiencing a financial crisis and it is from the necessary to complete the building of the house. Due to that crisis, Khaled couldn't complete all the building of the house and, he strives to finish all that building. Unfortunately, he doesn't have enough money to do that. 

Now, Khaled and his family live in a small and uncompleted house. The family can't afford this condition. In order to expand and complete the building of the house, Khaled is requesting a loan of 500,000 YER from AMB. He will use the loan to purchase construction materials as iron, cement, and bricks to expand and complete the building of his house.

Khaled's dream in the future is building more than one floor and renovating it. He also hopes to open a saving account in AMB.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials such as iron, cement, and bricks to expand and complete the building of his house.

loans.name: Batkhuyag

texts.en:
Batkhuyag, 46 years old, lives with his wife and son in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. He has been working as operator of a heavy truck at a mining company since 2012. His wife sells clothes and bags to local people. 

The house they live in has deteriorated over the years. As winter is coming, he is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to buy building materials such as fiberglass, foam, shingles and bricks for house renovation. After renovation, his family will live in a comfortable and warm place where less coal is burned and less pollutants are released into air.

loans.use: to renovate his house in order to burn less coal for heating.

loans.name: Bawi Lestari 2 Group

texts.en:
Ni Nyoman is the head of the Bawi Lestari 2 group. They make their daily living as farmers and pig farmers in the village of Baturiti, North Bali.

Ni Nyoman is trying to develop her pig business and previously took a loan from the MUK. From the sale of 3 pigs, Ni Nyoman managed to get a profit of 600,000 IDR. The gain was very helpful to the family's finances as they are currently experiencing difficult times due to increasingly expensive necessities of life. One member decided to resign after she successfully sold her pigs and earned a satisfactory profit. 

Ni Nyoman, with Bawi Lestari 2 group, decided to continue borrowing from the MUK as it is especially helpful in developing pig businesses. Because the price of pigs and pig feed seedlings is increasing, Ni Nyoman expects an increase in borrowing in the next period of time.

This is Bawi Lestari 2 group's fifth loan. It is a loan amount of 24,500,000 IDR. The loan in this current period will be used to buy piglets, sows and also to support any other businesses owned by members such as a small kiosk.

Ni Nyoman, head of the group, will be using her portion of the loan to buy two piglets and the rest will be used to fix their cage. She plans to keep a sow and become a piglet seller. Currently the price is quite expensive for piglets, 600,000 IDR per piglet. 

Ni Nyoman has a dream that this business will become a major source of family income.

loans.use: to buy two piglets and the rest to fix the cage

loans.name: Epefania

texts.en:
Epefania has been growing rice to provide for her family. She gets up early and has to go to her farm where she oversees her crops. She solely provides for her family and she is hoping to have better farm produce. 

She has repaid successfully her previous loan used for farming. She took a new loan recently to purchase fertilizer for this cropping season. In the future, she wants to provide a better living to her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for this cropping season.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora works hard to support her family. Leonora is married and has a pig fattening business in the Philippines.

Leonora requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Leonora has been in this business for 4 years now.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Leonora would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Aleyda Marilu

texts.es:
Aleyda, solicita un nuevo préstamo para invertirlo en yuca, maíz, papas, elotes, aceite, condimentos, variedad de pan etc., son materiales con los que podrá elaborar la venta de antojitos y seguir vendiendo pan dulce, de esta manera espera continuar progresando.
EL préstamo anterior le ha permitido a la Sra. Aleyda fortalecer el negocio, aumentar su inventario, atraer nuevos clientes y tener un mejor estilo de vida.
texts.en: Aleyda is requesting a new loan to buy cassava, corn, potatoes, corncobs, oil, condiments, diverse breads, etc. These are ingredients with which she will be able to make appetizers to sell, and to continue selling sweet bread. This way she hopes to continue progressing. The previous loan has allowed Aleyda to restock her inventory, to attract new customers and to have a better lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy cassava, corn, potatoes, corncobs, oil, condiments, different breads, etc. ingredients to prepare appetizers and continue selling sweet bread.

loans.name: Phatwell

texts.en:
Phatwell is 38 years old. He is married and has three children, two boys and a girl. All his children are in school. 

He operates his own Zoona mobile money transfer business. The business provides affordable and accessible financial services to people in his small town of Chadiza, located in the eastern province of Zambia.

Phatwell works very hard to support his family. He currently has a full-time job and juggles his time between his job and his mobile money transfers business. He has been running the business for nearly five years. Phatwell says his community benefits from his business because it is much cheaper and user-friendly for all customers.

Phatwell’s current challenge is accessing working capital so that he can grow his business and serve more customers. He explains that his business has not expanded much and the primary reason for this is the lack of capital needed to invest in the business so he can serve more customers. In serving more customers Phatwell will earn more income from making commissions off each transaction. Phatwell is hopeful that once he starts making this additional profit, he can one day be in a position to open a new shop at another location.

Phatwell is grateful for the opportunity to be connected with Kiva lenders. He says this loan is the beginning of great things for his family and growing the business.

loans.use: To grow his business by increasing the money that he uses to service his customers.

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en:
Novelyn is a 36-year-old married woman from Dulag, Leyte. For the last three years, she has been engaged in a sari-sari (variety) store business and a transportation business using her tricycle. With these businesses, she supports her three children, ages 3,11 and 12. 

Novelyn is requesting a loan to buy stocks of items like vinegar, soy sauce, canned goods, sugar, noodles, and cooking oil, and to pay for the repair of her tricycle.

Any income generated from this business will be used to provide her family with healthy meals and to pay school fees for her children. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and have other business options.

loans.use: to buy stocks of items like vinegar, soy sauce, canned goods, sugar, noodles, and cooking oil, and to pay for the repair of her tricycle.

loans.name: Angeli

texts.en:
Angeli has tried her luck at doing a business that focuses on her farming activities. She has approached Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for her capital needs.  

She has borrowed an amount to pay for seedlings and compost. This loan will help give her farming income a big boost. 

Angeli looks for better business opportunities and would love to be in a position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 36-year-old woman married to Griffin, who adds additional income to support their family. They are blessed with three children.  

Mary has been operating a fish-selling stall for ten years, earning her an income of KES 10,000 at the end of every month.

Mary is now servicing her second loan of KES 22,500 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to buy more fish and add to her stock, which is running out.

Mary plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees to her children and hopes to become a major supplier of fish in her hometown.

loans.use: To buy additional fishes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Tolentina

texts.en:
Tolentina is a farmer from Liloy. She learned about Paglaum MPC and  borrowed a loan to start her rice production.
 
She was able to return her borrowed capital after several months. To this day, she feels she owes her good fortune to the cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used for her business. 

Recently, she availed a loan to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer for the next cropping season. Tolentina wishes to sustain her business and be able to supply rice in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel runs a bakery to make a living. He work hard on his business because he wants to help his parents.

He has joined Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative and has taken out a loan to purchase raw ingredients for his bakery.

He has started accepting orders for meetings and other occasions. He wants to expand  this business to earn more income and be able to save for his own future needs. 

He hopes to gain more income and plans to use his revenue for business capital.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for his bakery

loans.name: Igball

texts.en:
Igball wants to thank all of the lenders for the previous loan, which has helped her to purchase a cow. She was able to enjoy more income and profit from this cow, improving her living standards.

Now she is requesting a second loan to purchase another milk cow. She hopes that she will see the same result and increase her income from this addition as she has seen there is a high demand for the milk she provides. She hopes that in the future she can expand her farm into being a very large and profitable business. 

She is very grateful for this opportunity again and wants to thank all of the lenders.

loans.use: To purchase another milk cow.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 29 years old and lives in Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines, with her husband and three children. 
 
Rosemary realized there were ways to help raise income for her family. She joined Paglaum Cooperative, which helped her in the capitalization of her sari-sari (small grocery) store in January of 2012. She became a MIGS member, which is why she has received loans several times already. 

Now, she applies for 14,900 PHP to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store. She hopes that her business will continue and someday become a mini-grocery.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Yesenia Aracely

texts.es:
Yesenia de 20 años edad, estudio hasta noveno grado. Comenta que por la situación económica de su familia no logro seguir estudiando.  Ella está acompañada su esposo es empleado trabaja como lector en una empresa y realiza cultivos de maíz y frijol, ellos son padres de 1 hijo de 3 años de edad.
		 
Yesenia se dedica a impartir clases de alfabetización a grupos de personas mayores, comenta que tiene ya 2 años de dedicarse a esta actividad, que es algo que le gusta mucho enseñar a leer y a escribir a personas que no han tenido la oportunidad de estudiar, el trabajo lo obtuvo gracias a una amiga que la recomendó para que pudiera trabajar y hoy en día es una excelente empleada todo esto por su dedicación y compromiso con la actividad que realiza, el horario de trabajo es por las tardes de 3:00 pm a 5:00 pm. Yesenia también se dedica a los oficios domésticos en su vivienda y cuidar de su hijo en los tiempos libre. 

El préstamo que está solicitando, es para la preparación de la tierra, pago de mano de obra y compra de fertilizantes, para cultivar frijol. Esta actividad es realiza por su esposo  y de estas cosechas almacenan para su alimentación y otra parte la venden.
